questions.text:
Consider the following statements about sympathetic, parasympathetic, and motor nerves. Which of the following statements are true? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

 

  1. Sympathetic efferent are distributed all over the body/ extensively whereas parasympathetic distribution is limited.
  2. Sympathetic fibers travel long distances after leaving the sympathetic chain, before finally synapsing and then a shorter distance to effector organs.
  3. Parasympathetic fibers travel a shorter distance to their respective ganglia which are located close to the target organs.
  4. Motor neurons are located in the ventral horn of the spinal cord from where the axons come out and divide into several branches, each of which supplies an individual muscle fiber.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 4

 

Explanation

 

The true statements are:

 

Statement 1. Sympathetic efferents are distributed all over the body extensively, whereas parasympathetic distribution is limited. Sympathetic fibers provide widespread distribution throughout the body, innervating various organs and tissues. In contrast, parasympathetic fibers have a more restricted distribution, primarily targeting the head, neck, and trunk regions.

 

Statement 4. Motor neurons are located in the ventral horn of the spinal cord from where the axons come out and divide into several branches, each of which supplies an individual muscle fiber. Motor neurons originate in the ventral horn of the spinal cord, and their axons branch out to innervate individual muscle fibers, facilitating voluntary muscle movements.

 

Other Options:

 

Statement 2: Incorrect. Sympathetic fibers do not travel long distances after leaving the sympathetic chain before synapsing. Instead, sympathetic preganglionic fibers travel a short distance to the ganglia (which are located close to the spinal cord) and then the postganglionic fibers travel a long distance to reach the effector organs.

 

Statement 3: Incorrect. Parasympathetic fibers travel a long distance to their respective ganglia which are located close to or within the target organs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sympathetic efferent are distributed all over the body/ extensively whereas parasympathetic distribution is limited to head neck and trunk

choices.text: Located in the thick muscle layer
Afferent fibers pass via the glossopharyngeal nerve branch
Sensitive to changes in arterial pressure

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about baroreceptors? (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Located in the thick muscle layer

 

Baroreceptors are located in the adventitial layer of the carotid bulb of the internal carotid artery (not in the thick muscle layer); where the walls are typically thinner to allow for the detection of pressure changes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Stretch receptors: Baroreceptors are indeed stretch receptors; they respond to the stretching of the arterial wall as blood pressure changes.

 

Option C. Afferent fibers pass via the glossopharyngeal nerve branch: Afferent fibers from the carotid sinus baroreceptors pass through the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) to the brainstem.

 

Option D. Sensitive to changes in arterial pressure: Baroreceptors are sensitive to changes in arterial pressure; they quickly respond to fluctuations in blood pressure by sending signals to the central nervous system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Baroreceptors are located in the adventitial layer, not in the thick muscle layer, and they are sensitive to changes in arterial pressure, functioning as stretch receptors with afferent fibers passing via the glossopharyngeal nerve.`1

questions.text: The persistence of ADHD in childhood increases the risk of development of which of the following in adolescence? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Conduct disorder

 

Children with Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) are at an increased risk of developing conduct disorder during adolescence. ADHD is characterized by impulsivity, hyperactivity, and inattention, which can lead to difficulty in following rules, controlling behavior, and maintaining social norms. When these symptoms persist into adolescence, they can manifest as more serious behavioral problems, such as conduct disorder, characterized by aggressive, antisocial, or defiant behaviors.

 

Conduct disorder is a common progression from ADHD because the underlying impulsivity and lack of self-control associated with ADHD often worsen over time, particularly when untreated. This progression underscores the importance of early intervention in managing ADHD symptoms.

 

Note - Children with ADHD are at risk of developing depression, antisocial personality disorder, substance use disorder, and conduct disorder as adults.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Selective mutism: This disorder involves a consistent failure to speak in specific social situations despite speaking in other situations, and it is more associated with anxiety disorders rather than ADHD.

 

Option C. Binge eating disorder: This condition involves recurrent episodes of eating large quantities of food, often quickly and to the point of discomfort. It is associated more with emotional regulation issues rather than impulsivity or behavioral problems typical of ADHD.

 

Option D. Separation anxiety disorder: This disorder is characterized by excessive fear or anxiety about separation from attachment figures. It is more commonly associated with anxiety disorders and does not have a direct link to ADHD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The persistence of ADHD in childhood significantly increases the risk of developing conduct disorder during adolescence, highlighting the need for early and effective management of ADHD symptoms.

questions.text:
Organize the subsequent afferent columns in the floor of the fourth ventricle, proceeding from the medial to the lateral direction. (INICET MAY 2023)

 

1. General somatic

2. General visceral

3. Special somatic

4. Special visceral
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 2, 4, 1, 3

 

The question is regarding afferent columns hence we will only look at the afferent columns to arrange these options and not the whole arrangement of all the columns in the diagram.

 

The afferent columns in the floor of the fourth ventricle can be categorized from medial to lateral into four types: general visceral, special visceral, general somatic, and special somatic.

 

 

 

The subsequent afferent columns in the floor of the fourth ventricle can be organized from medial to lateral as follows:

 

2. General visceral: The general visceral column carries sensory information from the internal organs, such as the visceral sensations of hunger, fullness, and discomfort.

 

4. Special visceral: This column includes sensory input related to the special senses of taste and hearing. The special visceral sensory column carries information from the taste buds and the cochlea (auditory part of the ear).

 

1. General somatic: The general somatic column carries sensory information related to touch, temperature, pain, and pressure from the body's skin and musculoskeletal system.

 

3. Special somatic: This column contains sensory input related to the special senses of vision, equilibrium, and proprioception (awareness of body position). It includes input from the eyes, ears (for balance), and proprioceptors in muscles and joints.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the floor of the fourth ventricle, the arrangement of the afferent sensory columns from medial to lateral is - 2. General visceral, 4. Special visceral, 1. General somatic & 3. Special somatic

questions.text: Match the given cellular components with their respective marker enzymes?  (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-D, 2-A, 3-B, 4-C

 

The correct matches of cellular components with their marker enzymes are:

 

  1. Mitochondria - ATP synthase (D): ATP synthase is a key enzyme in the mitochondria involved in the synthesis of ATP, making it a marker enzyme for this organelle.
  2. Peroxisomes - Catalase (A): Catalase is an enzyme found in peroxisomes that helps in the breakdown of hydrogen peroxide, making it a characteristic marker for peroxisomes.
  3. Golgi complex - Galactosyl transferase (B): Galactosyl transferase is involved in the glycosylation processes in the Golgi complex, serving as a marker enzyme for this organelle.
  4. Endoplasmic reticulum - Glucose-6-phosphatase (C): Glucose-6-phosphatase is found in the endoplasmic reticulum and is involved in glucose metabolism, making it a marker enzyme for this structure.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
What is the sequence of heart sounds heard from the top to the bottom of the left side of the chest wall? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Pulmonary
  2. Aortic
  3. Mitral
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1 ➔ 2 ➔ 3
 

The sequence of cardiac sounds as they're perceived on the left side of the chest, from top to bottom, is outlined below:

 

  1. Pulmonary - detected in the second intercostal space.
  2. Aortic - can be heard at the neoaortic region or Erb's point, situated in the second intercostal space.
  3. Mitral - observed at the fifth intercostal space.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence of heart sounds heard from the top to the bottom of the left side of the chest wall is: Pulmonary (second intercostal space), Aortic (second intercostal space), and Mitral (fifth intercostal space).

choices.text: Partial fixation of footplate of stapes

questions.text: What causes maximum hearing loss? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ossicular discontinuity with intact TM

 

Ossicular discontinuity with intact tympanic membrane causes maximum hearing loss (around 50 dB) because:

 

  • Sound waves can only travel through the ossicular chain when it is intact
  • When there's a break in the ossicular chain, sound transmission is completely interrupted
  • With intact TM, there's no alternative pathway for sound to reach the inner ear
  • The sound waves get dampened at the point of discontinuity

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Otitis media with effusion

 

  • Causes mild conductive hearing loss (30-35 dB)
  • Middle ear filled with serous fluid still allows some sound transmission
  • Common in children with adenoid hypertrophy blocking Eustachian tube

 

Option B. Partial fixation of footplate of stapes

 

  • Represents early otosclerosis
  • Causes mild conductive hearing loss as stapes can still move partially
  • Less severe than complete ossicular discontinuity

 

Option D. Malleus-incus disruption with TM disruption

 

  • Causes around 40 dB hearing loss
  • Less severe than option C because sound waves can reach round window directly through the perforation
  • Provides an alternative pathway for sound transmission

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ossicular discontinuity with intact tympanic membrane causes maximum hearing loss (50 dB) because sound waves have no alternative pathway to reach the inner ear.

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of cirrhosis of the liver presents with abdominal distension and swelling of the lower limbs. The preferred diuretic for this patient would be?(INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Eplerenone

 

  • Eplerenone is a mineralocorticoid (Aldosterone) receptor antagonist and a potassium sparing diuretic. In a patient of cirrhosis, there is splanchnic vasodilation, due to which there is decreased effective arterial blood volume. This stimulates the RAAS axis and as a result, the levels of Aldosterone are increased. Aldosterone ultimately leads to increased absorption of Na+ and water from the late distal tubules and collecting ducts along with excretion of K+ and H+ into the lumen.
  • This increased sodium and water retention leads to the development of ascites and edema.
  • Eplerenone, like Spironolactone, blocks this action of Aldosterone and leads to natriuresis and diuresis, without causing loss of K+. Therefore, it is the preferred drug in this patient.
  • It is important to note that in clinical practice, a combination of a loop diuretic (like furosemide) and an aldosterone antagonist (like spironolactone or eplerenone) is typically used for managing ascites and peripheral edema in cirrhosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Triamterene: Triamterene is also a potassium-sparing diuretic, but it works by blocking sodium channels in the distal nephron. It is less effective than aldosterone antagonists like eplerenone in managing ascites related to cirrhosis.

 

Option C. Chlorthalidone: Chlorthalidone is a thiazide-like diuretic that inhibits sodium reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule. Thiazide diuretics are not as effective in the setting of cirrhosis with ascites and are not typically used for this purpose.

 

Option D. Acetazolamide: Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that acts on the proximal tubule. It is used primarily to treat metabolic alkalosis and glaucoma, and is not suitable for treating ascites and peripheral edema in cirrhosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eplerenone, as a mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist and potassium-sparing diuretic, is the preferred choice for managing ascites and peripheral edema in patients with cirrhosis due to its ability to counteract the effects of elevated aldosterone levels.

questions.text:
Mrs. Smith has been referred to the plastic surgery department for the reconstruction of a large wound on her thigh. After a thorough examination, the surgeon decides to perform a skin graft. While discussing the procedure with Mrs. Smith, the surgeon explains the difference between split skin and full-thickness skin grafts. Identify the true statement regarding split thickness and full-thickness skin grafts:(INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. Primary contracture is more in split skin grafts
  2. Secondary contracture is more in split skin grafts
  3. Primary contracture is more in full-thickness grafts
  4. Secondary contracture is more in full-thickness grafts
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2, 3

 

Split skin grafts are partial-thickness skin grafts consisting of the epidermis and a part of the dermis, while full-thickness grafts consist of the epidermis along with the entire dermis, with portions of the sweat glands, sebaceous glands, and hair follicles. Primary contracture of the skin graft occurs due to passive recoil of the elastin fibers of the dermis in full thickness grafts. Since full-thickness grafts have more dermis (implying more elastin fibers), they undergo more primary contracture than split skin grafts.

 

Secondary contracture of the skin graft occurs due to the pull of myofibroblasts, and it occurs over time, when the transplanted graft starts healing. Full-thickness grafts have more ability to resist the pull of myofibroblasts, hence they have less secondary contracture than split skin grafts.

 

Primary contracture: FTSG

 

Secondary contracture: STSG

 

Thus, statements 2 and 3 are correct.

questions.text:
Which of the following muscles form the pelvic diaphragm?(INICET MAY 2023)

 

1. Iliococcygeus

2. Pubococcygeus

3. Obturator internus

4. Deep transverse perinei
questions.solution:
Ans. A.  1, 2

 

The Iliococcygeus and pubococcygeus muscles are components of the pelvic diaphragm, commonly referred to as the levator ani.

 

The pelvic diaphragm is a muscular partition between the true pelvis and the perineum. It is formed by the large levator ani and small coccygeus muscles of two sides and their covering fasciae.

 

 

1. Iliococcygeus: The iliococcygeus is one of the muscles that form the pelvic diaphragm. It is part of the levator ani muscle group. The levator ani consists of the iliococcygeus, pubococcygeus, and puborectalis muscles. The iliococcygeus muscle extends from the ischial spine (a bony projection in the pelvis) to the coccyx (the tailbone) and contributes to the support of the pelvic floor.
 

2. Pubococcygeus: The pubococcygeus muscle is another component of the levator ani muscle group and is a part of the pelvic diaphragm. It extends from the pubic bone to the coccyx and helps maintain pelvic organ support and control.

 

Other Options:

 

3. Obturator Internus: The obturator internus is not considered a part of the pelvic diaphragm. It is a separate muscle located in the pelvic region, and its primary function is to laterally rotate the thigh. While it is near the pelvic diaphragm, it does not contribute to its formation.
 

4. Deep Transverse Perinei: The deep transverse perineal muscles are not typically considered part of the pelvic diaphragm. These muscles are located in the perineum (the area between the anus and the genitalia) and play a role in stabilizing the perineal body and supporting the pelvic organs. They are important for urinary and fecal continence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pelvic diaphragm is formed by the iliococcygeus and pubococcygeus muscles (part of the levator ani muscle group). The obturator internus and deep transverse perineal muscles are nearby but are not considered part of the pelvic diaphragm itself.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female, who had visited multiple plastic surgeons requesting correction of "face deformity," was referred to a Psychiatrist. The patient insists that her face is deformed and needs surgery despite no evidence of deformity in the examination. The patient persists with her demand despite family members’ and doctors' reassurances. What is the management? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) SSRI

 

The patient described in the question is suffering from Body Dysmorphic Disorder (BDD). BDD is a mental health condition characterized by an excessive preoccupation with an imagined defect in appearance, or if a minor physical anomaly is present, the person's concern is markedly excessive. Patients often have poor or absent insight, believing firmly in the existence of their perceived defects.

 

The standard treatment for BDD includes Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors (SSRIs) (DOC) and Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT). Even when a patient's insight is at a delusional level, SSRIs remain the first-line pharmacological treatment, as they help reduce obsessive thoughts and compulsive behaviors associated with the disorder. In this case, SSRIs would be the best management option.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Behavioural therapy: While behavioral therapy might offer some benefits, the specific first-line treatment for BDD is Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT), which targets the distorted beliefs about appearance directly. The term "Behavioral Therapy" is broad and less specific, making SSRIs a more targeted choice.

 

Option C. Atypical antipsychotics: These medications are not considered first-line treatment for BDD. They may be used as adjuncts in severe cases where delusional beliefs persist despite SSRIs, but they are not the primary treatment.

 

Option D. Allow her for surgery: Surgery is not a recommended treatment for BDD as it does not address the underlying psychiatric condition and often worsens the patient's mental health state by reinforcing their preoccupation with appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Body Dysmorphic Disorder (BDD), especially when insight is poor or absent, SSRIs are the drug of choice for management, often in combination with Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT). Surgery is contraindicated as it does not address the core psychological issue.

choices.text: 10% of lung cancers in smokers is not associated with smoking
90% cases of lung cancer can be eliminated in population if smoking is eliminated
90% cases of lung cancer can be eliminated in smokers if smoking is eliminated
10% cases of lung cancer can be eliminated in population if smoking is eliminated

questions.text: A 45-year-old researcher is keenly interested in understanding the relationship between lung cancer and smoking habits. After conducting an extensive study and analyzing his data, he finds that the attributable risk is 90%. Which of the following is the most accurate interpretation of this result? [INICET NOV 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) 10% of lung cancers in smokers is not associated with smoking

 

  • In the given scenario, the attributable risk of cigarette smoking to lung cancer is 90%; hence, 90% cases of lung cancer are due to smoking as a risk factor
  • The difference between the incidence of disease among exposed and the incidence among non-exposed is given by the attributable risk.
  • Attributable risk is the difference in risk of disease between two groups (exposed and non-exposed) and represents the proportion of disease occurrence that can be attributed to the exposure.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Interpretation of AR (attributable risk): AR is indicative of the extent of the disease attributed to the exposure
  • Interpretation of PAR (Population attributable risk): If risk factor is modified or eliminated, there will be so much annual reduction in incidence of disease in the given population

questions.text: The leading cause of bladder outlet obstruction in male children is: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Posterior urethral valve

 

This is the most common cause of lower urinary tract obstruction in male infants. PUV is a congenital malformation found only in boys where there is an abnormal fold of tissue in the posterior urethra, preventing normal urine outflow and leading to bladder outlet obstruction. The condition can lead to hydronephrosis if not treated promptly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urethral atresia: This is a rare congenital anomaly where a segment of the urethra fails to canalize or develop. It leads to complete obstruction of the urethra, and while it does cause bladder outlet obstruction, it is less common than PUV in male children.

 

Option C. Anterior urethral valve: This is a rare congenital anomaly and is much less common than the posterior urethral valve. While it can cause obstruction, its prevalence and significance in causing bladder outlet obstruction in male children are far less than that of PUV.

 

Option D. Ureterocele: A ureterocele is a cystic dilation of the terminal ureter within the bladder. It can cause obstruction of the ureter itself. They are not the leading cause in male children when compared to PUV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most frequent cause of bladder outflow obstruction in male children is the posterior urethral valve (PUV).
  • PUV is a membranous fold located in the posterior urethra, typically found just distal to the verumontanum. It is thought to occur due to the persistence of the urogenital membrane.
  • Urethral obstruction can cause dilation of the posterior urethral valve, bladder, and bilateral hydronephrosis, leading to a keyhole sign on prenatal ultrasound and potentially oligohydramnios.
  • If not detected prenatally, PUV may present postnatally as a newborn or young infant with urinary tract symptoms, abdominal distension or and recurrent UTIs.
  • Left untreated, PUV may result in chronic kidney disease, bladder dysfunction, and vesicoureteral reflux.
  • Diagnosis of PUV is typically based on the presence of an elongated posterior valve during the voiding phase of the voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG).

questions.text: The given diagram shows the steps in bacterial cell wall formation. Identify the site of action of beta-lactam antibiotics. (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 4

 

Beta lactams act on step 4 in the given image.

 

The beta lactams inhibit the formation of bacterial cell wall by inhibiting the Transpeptidase enzyme which is required for the cross linking of the peptidoglycan chains; therefore, they lead to a reduction in the strength of the bacterial cell wall which ultimately causes it to burst, leading to the death of the bacteria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1: Fosfomycin inhibits step 1 in the image. It inhibits the cytoplasmic enzyme enol pyruvate transferase that catalyses the initial step in the bacterial cell wall synthesis. It is used for the treatment of urinary tract infections.

 

Option B. 2: Bacitracin inhibits step 2 in the image. It is a cell wall synthesis inhibitor that interferes with dephosphorylation of the BP transporter which transfers peptidoglycan subunits to the growing cell wall.

 

Option C. 3: Vancomycin inhibits step 3 in the image. It binds to the D-Ala-D-Ala terminus of the newly formed peptidoglycan pentapeptide. This prevents further elongation of the peptidoglycan and its cross-linking by inhibiting transglycolase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beta-lactam antibiotics act at step 4 in the bacterial cell wall synthesis process by inhibiting transpeptidase enzymes, which are essential for cross-linking peptidoglycan chains, thereby weakening the bacterial cell wall and causing cell lysis.

questions.text: A patient presents with recurrent urinary tract infections and lower abdominal tenderness. Digital rectal examination reveals a normal prostate. Urine microscopy shows plenty of pus cells, but no organisms are detected on culture. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sterile pyuria

 

The clinical presentation describes a patient with recurrent urinary tract infections, lower abdominal tenderness, normal prostate examination, and urine culture showing pus cells but no visible organisms. This constellation of findings is characteristic of sterile pyuria.

 

Sterile pyuria occurs when there are white blood cells (pus cells) in the urine but no organisms are visible on standard urine culture. The most common cause of sterile pyuria is Chlamydia trachomatis infection. Chlamydia is an intracellular organism that cannot be seen on routine urine culture, hence the term "sterile" pyuria. This organism is the most common cause of non-gonococcal urethritis (NGU) and presents with urinary symptoms and pyuria without visible organisms on standard culture methods.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute prostatitis: The question specifically states that prostate examination was normal, ruling out both acute and chronic prostatitis.

 

Option B. Granulomatous disease: Granulomatous diseases would typically present with additional features like epithelioid cells, granuloma formation, or necrosis, none of which are mentioned in this case.

 

Option D. Chronic prostatitis : Again, the normal prostate examination rules out prostatitis (both acute and chronic forms).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sterile pyuria (pus cells in urine without visible organisms on culture) is commonly caused by Chlamydia trachomatis, the leading cause of non-gonococcal urethritis.

questions.text: Which structures pass between superior and middle constrictor?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IX nerve (Glossopharyngeal Nerve)

 

The pharyngeal constrictor muscles are organized into three main parts: the superior, middle, and inferior constrictors. Each of these muscles plays a crucial role in the mechanics of swallowing and speech.

 

The glossopharyngeal nerve passes between the superior and middle constrictor muscles. This is a key anatomical relationship to remember as it is crucial for the nerve supply to the pharynx.

Other Options:

 

Option A. Eustachian Tube: Passes through the sinus of Morgagni, not between the superior and middle constrictors.

 

Option C. Superior Laryngeal Nerve: Passes between the middle and inferior constrictors, not the superior and middle constrictors.

 

Option D. Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve: Passes between the inferior constrictor and the esophagus, not between the superior and middle constrictors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The IX nerve (Glossopharyngeal nerve) and the stylopharyngeus muscle pass between the superior and middle constrictor muscles of the pharynx.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma (JNA) is incorrect? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Biopsy done under L/A

 

Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) is a highly vascular benign tumor that exclusively affects adolescent males. Biopsy is absolutely contraindicated in JNA because it is a vascular tumor with absent contractile muscular components in blood vessel walls. Any attempt to perform a biopsy (whether punch biopsy, needle biopsy, or any other form) will result in profuse, uncontrollable bleeding that is extremely difficult to manage. This is a fundamental in managing vascular tumors - never biopsy suspected JNA, glomus tumors, or hemangiomas.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Recurrent epistaxis: This is correct for JNA. Profuse, recurrent nosebleeds are the hallmark presentation of JNA, often described as heavy nasal bleeding that cannot be controlled by regular clinical measures.

 

Option B. Unilateral nasal obstruction: This is correct for JNA. The tumor typically causes progressive nasal obstruction, which can be unilateral initially but may become bilateral as the tumor grows.

 

Option C. Exclusively adolescent male: This is correct for JNA. This tumor has a unique demographic pattern, occurring only in adolescent males, making this a pathognomonic feature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Biopsy is contraindicated in juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma due to risk of uncontrollable hemorrhage.



Note -

questions.text:
Organize the subsequent structures in the auditory pathway, beginning from the receptors and moving towards the cortex: (INICET May 2023)

 

  1. Auditory Cortex
  2. Spiral ganglion
  3. Cochlear Nucleus
  4. Lateral leminiscus
  5. Inferior colliculus
  6. Olivary complex
  7. Medial geniculate body
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2-3-6-4-5-7-1

 

The correct sequence of structures in the auditory pathway, beginning from the receptors (cochlea) and moving towards the auditory cortex, is as follows:

 

2. Spiral ganglion: The auditory nerve fibers originate here.

 

3. Cochlear Nucleus: The auditory nerve fibers synapse in the cochlear nuclei located in the brainstem.

 

6. Olivary complex: After the cochlear nucleus, the pathway proceeds to the superior olivary complex.

 

4. Lateral lemniscus: From the superior olivary complex, the auditory signals travel via the lateral lemniscus.

 

5. Inferior colliculus: The lateral lemniscus projects to the inferior colliculus in the midbrain.

 

7. Medial geniculate body: The signals are then relayed to the medial geniculate body of the thalamus.

 

1. Auditory Cortex: Finally, the signals reach the auditory cortex (Area 41) in the temporal lobe for processing.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

AUDITORY PATHWAY

 

E – Eighth nerve

 

C – Cochlear nucleus

 

O – Olivary complex (superior)

 

L – Lateral lemniscus

 

I – Inferior colliculus

 

M – Medial geniculate body

 

A – Auditory cortex

questions.text: Which of the following functions is performed by the layer marked in the given histological section? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sodium and water retention

 

The image shows the adrenal gland, which is divided into the cortex and the medulla. The cortex is further subdivided into three layers: the zona glomerulosa, zona fasciculata, and zona reticularis.

 

  • Zona Glomerulosa: This is the outermost layer of the adrenal cortex and is responsible for the production of mineralocorticoids, primarily aldosterone. Aldosterone plays a key role in regulating sodium and water balance in the body, leading to sodium retention and water reabsorption in the kidneys.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gluconeogenesis: Gluconeogenesis is primarily a function of the zona fasciculata, which secretes glucocorticoids (e.g., cortisol) that promote glucose synthesis and metabolism.

 

Option C. Increased sex hormones: The zona reticularis is responsible for producing androgens, which are sex hormones. It does not contribute to sodium and water retention.

 

Option D. Immune cell interaction: While glucocorticoids from the zona fasciculata have some immunosuppressive effects, immune cell interaction is not a primary function of the marked layer, which is the zona glomerulosa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The zona glomerulosa of the adrenal cortex is responsible for sodium and water retention through the secretion of mineralocorticoids, primarily aldosterone.

questions.text: A scientist is culturing a virus using the RT-PCR technique and performs 26 amplification cycles. After how many cycles would the DNA quantity be approximately half of what is present at the 26th cycle? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 25

 

In PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction), each cycle doubles the amount of DNA present. This means that after each cycle, the DNA quantity increases exponentially according to the formula 2(n), where n is the number of cycles.

 

After 26 cycles, the amount of DNA = 2(26)

 

To find when the DNA amount would be half of that observed at the 26th cycle:

 

  • Half of 2(26) = ½ x 2(26) = 2-1 × 226 = 225

 

Therefore, after 25 cycles, the amount of DNA would be exactly half of what is observed at the 26th cycle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In PCR, each cycle doubles the DNA amount; therefore, to get half the DNA amount from cycle n, you need cycle (n-1).

questions.text: A 38-year-old civil engineer is working on a construction project in an area recently affected by a devastating earthquake. To prevent future devastation, the local government has amended the building codes. These changes are aimed at ensuring structures in the area can better withstand seismic activity. The engineer reviews the changes to determine the best approach for the new construction project. This modification to the building codes is primarily an example of which phase of disaster management? [INICET NOV 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Disaster mitigation

 

  • The measures that are taken to prevent disasters from causing emergencies or to lessen the likely effects of emergencies are part of disaster mitigation.
  • Mitigation involves measures designed either to prevent hazards from causing an emergency or to lessen the likely effects of emergencies. In most cases mitigation measures aim to reduce the vulnerability of the system.

 

In Disaster Cycle, the steps involved are –

 

  1. Disaster Impact and Response: it involves search, rescue, first aid of the patients, triaging them according to the severity of their injuries and their likelihood of survival with prompt medical intervention, tagging and identification of dead.
  2. Relief Phase or Disaster Containment by prompt assistance, epidemiological surveillance and disease control, vaccination, nutritional support.
  3. Rehabilitation involves restoration of the pre-disaster conditions. It takes into account assessment and restoration of water supply, food safety and supply, basic sanitation, personal hygiene, vector control.
  4. Disaster Mitigation involves measures aimed at reducing or preventing the hazards from causing any emergency or to dampen the effects of emergencies. It involves flood mitigation works, appropriate land-use planning, improved building codes and reduction or protection of vulnerable population and structures.
  5. Disaster Preparedness is a long-term programme of developmental activities which aims at strengthening the overall capacity and capability of the country to efficiently and effectively manage all the emergencies.  

 

   

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Disaster mitigation involves proactive measures such as improved building codes to reduce the impact of future disasters, aiming to lessen vulnerability and enhance resilience against potential hazards.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with complaints of vertigo, sensorineural hearing loss and tinnitus which lasts minutes to hours with accompanied nausea and vomiting. On investigation, there is endolymphatic hypertension present. What is the diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Meniere’s disease

The patient's symptoms and the diagnostic finding of endolymphatic hypertension align with Meniere's disease. 

Characterized by episodes of vertigo, sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and aural fullness, lasting from minutes to hours. The symptoms are due to the accumulation of fluid in the inner ear (endolymphatic hydrops), leading to increased pressure within the endolymphatic system.

Other Options:

 Option B. Otosclerosis: A condition primarily affecting the bones of the middle ear, particularly the stapes. It causes conductive hearing loss, not typically associated with vertigo or tinnitus of the type seen in Meniere’s disease.

Option C. Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV): Characterized by brief episodes of vertigo related to changes in head position. It involves the dislodgment of otoliths within the inner ear, leading to brief, intense episodes of vertigo, without the auditory symptoms typical of Meniere's disease. 

Option D. Acoustic Neuroma (Vestibular Schwannoma): A benign tumor on the vestibular nerve, leading to progressive, unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and balance disturbances. It usually does not cause episodic vertigo like Meniere's disease.

Educational Objective:

Meniere’s disease is a chronic condition that requires management of symptoms through lifestyle changes, medications to control vertigo, and sometimes more invasive treatments to manage fluid pressure in the inner ear.

choices.text: Hemophilus alters penicillin binding protein sites, hence resistant to ampicillin
Easier to administer IV ceftriaxone than IV ampicillin
Cotrimoxazole is the drug of choice, but patient is allergic to sulfa drugs
Hemophilus produces beta lactamase, hence resistant to ampicillin

questions.text: A 14-month-old boy was diagnosed with Hemophilus influenza meningitis. The initial treatment plan was to start on ampicillin but later was shifted to ceftriaxone. What could be the probable reason? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Hemophilus produces beta lactamase, hence resistant to ampicillin  

 

Hemophilus influenzae, particularly some strains, can produce beta-lactamase, an enzyme that breaks down the beta-lactam ring found in penicillins (like ampicillin) and some other antibiotics. This enzymatic activity renders these bacteria resistant to the effects of these antibiotics. Due to the increasing prevalence of beta-lactamase-producing H. influenzae, the use of ampicillin alone is often not recommended for serious infections like meningitis. Ceftriaxone, a third-generation cephalosporin, is a preferred choice as it is more resistant to beta-lactamase and has good central nervous system penetration, which is essential for the treatment of meningitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemophilus alters penicillin-binding protein sites, hence resistant to ampicillin: While changes in penicillin-binding proteins can confer resistance to beta-lactam antibiotics, this is not the primary mechanism of resistance in H. influenzae. The major concern is beta-lactamase production.

 

Option B. Easier to administer IV ceftriaxone than IV ampicillin: While the ease of administration might be a consideration in some cases (ceftriaxone can be given once a day due to its long half-life), the primary concern in this scenario is antibiotic efficacy and resistance patterns, not the convenience of administration.

 

Option C. Cotrimoxazole is the drug of choice, but the patient is allergic to sulfa drugs: Cotrimoxazole (trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole) is not the primary drug of choice for H. influenzae meningitis. The first-line treatment is usually a third-generation cephalosporin like ceftriaxone or cefotaxime.

 

Therefore, the most probable reason for switching from ampicillin to ceftriaxone in this case is the beta-lactamase production by H. influenzae, making it resistant to ampicillin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary reason for switching from ampicillin to ceftriaxone in the treatment of Hemophilus influenzae meningitis is the production of beta-lactamase by H. influenzae, which renders the bacteria resistant to ampicillin. Ceftriaxone is more resistant to beta-lactamase and provides effective CNS penetration, making it a more suitable choice for treating bacterial meningitis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered a contraindication to BCT? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tumor limited to one quadrant

 

Breast Conservation Therapy (BCT) involves wide local excision of the tumor followed by radiation therapy. A tumor limited to one quadrant is actually suitable for BCT as it allows for adequate wide local excision with clear margins while preserving most of the breast tissue. BCT is feasible when the tumor is localized and can be completely excised with negative margins while maintaining acceptable cosmesis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prior chest radiation: Incorrect. This is a contraindication to BCT because the breast tissue has already received radiation, and re-irradiation would exceed tissue tolerance, leading to severe complications including tissue necrosis and poor wound healing.

 

Option B. Involved margins after resection: Incorrect. This is a contraindication, especially if margins remain positive after two or more attempts at re-excision. Positive margins indicate incomplete tumor removal and high risk of local recurrence.

 

Option C. Scleroderma: Incorrect. This is a contraindication because scleroderma and other connective tissue disorders cause poor tolerance to radiation therapy, resulting in severe fibrosis, contractures, and poor cosmetic outcomes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tumor limited to one quadrant is not a contraindication to BCT; rather, it is an ideal scenario for breast conservation therapy.

choices.text: MRI to rule out enlarged heart

questions.text: The parents notice that their child is tired and that he has shortness of breath on climbing stairs and while lying down. What is the first investigation that you would do? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chest x-ray

 

The first investigation to be done for a child who feels shortness of breath on climbing stairs and in the supine position is a chest x-ray.

 

The child having shortness of breath on dyspnea on exertion worsened in the supine position is orthopnea could be suggestive of congestive heart failure.

 

Causes -

 

  1. Respiratory causes include asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disorder (COPD), pneumonia, and pulmonary embolism.
  2. Cardiovascular causes include congestive heart failure (CH), pulmonary edema, valvular heart defect, and pulmonary hypertension.

 

Evaluation

 

  • Oxygen saturation at rest and during physical activity
  • Chest x-ray is the first diagnostic test as pulmonary pathology or pulmonary edema and signs of CHF may be seen

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: An echocardiogram to evaluate cardiac cause if the chest X-ray is abnormal

 

Option C: Spirometry to assess lung function when the chest x-ray is normal.

 

Option D: Cardiac MRI (Magnetic resonance imaging) is an emerging modality done to look for cardiomegaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a child presenting with shortness of breath on exertion and orthopnea, the first investigation should be a chest x-ray to evaluate potential pulmonary pathology and signs of congestive heart failure.

choices.text: It represents the extent of absorption of the drug and is calculated from the area under curve of the plasma concentration vs time graph
It represents distribution of the drug in different tissues and is calculated by dividing the plasma concentration with the amount of drug given
It represents the duration of action of the drug and is calculated from the half-life of the drug
It represents margin of safety of a drug and is calculated as a ratio of LD50 to ED50

questions.text: A new drug is tested in clinical trials and was found to have a therapeutic index of 20. Which of the following statements best describes the therapeutic index of the drug? (Fmge Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. It represents margin of safety of a drug and is calculated as a ratio of LD50 to ED50

 

The therapeutic index (TI) refers to LD50/ED50.

 

Therapeutic Index = LD50/ED50

 

Where,

 

  • LD50 (Median Lethal dose) is the lethal dose at which 50% of the subjects died.

  • ED50 (Median Effective dose) is the dose at which 50% of the subjects get the desired response.

 

The therapeutic index is therefore the margin of safety for a drug.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It represents the extent of absorption of the drug and is calculated from the area under curve of the plasma concentration vs time graph: This statement describes bioavailability, not the therapeutic index.

 

Option B. It represents distribution of the drug in different tissues and is calculated by dividing the plasma concentration with the amount of drug given: This statement describes the volume of distribution (Vd), not the therapeutic index.

 

Option C. It represents the duration of action of the drug and is calculated from the half-life of the drug: This statement describes the drug's half-life, not the therapeutic index.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The therapeutic index (TI) is a crucial parameter that represents the margin of safety for a drug. It is calculated as the ratio of LD50 to ED50, indicating the range between an effective dose and a potentially lethal dose. A higher TI indicates a safer drug with a wider margin of safety.

questions.text: In the provided anatomical image, determine the type of joint represented by the marked structure. (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Saddle

 

  • The marked joint in the image is the incudo-malleolar joint, which is a type of saddle joint. This joint is located in the middle ear and involves the malleus and incus bones. The mnemonic "SBI" helps remember the types of joints in relation to the incus:
    • S for Saddle joint (incudo-malleolar joint)
    • B for Ball and socket joint (incudo-stapedial joint)
    • I for the Incus, positioned in front and behind the respective joints.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ball and socket: Incorrect. The ball and socket joint is found in the incudo-stapedial joint, not the incudo-malleolar joint.

 

Option C. Plane: Incorrect. The plane joint is not represented in the middle ear ossicles.

 

Option D. Gliding: Incorrect. Gliding joints are not present in the middle ear ossicles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The incudo-malleolar joint is a saddle joint, an important anatomical feature in the middle ear.

questions.text: What are the tactile hallucinations observed in instances of prolonged cocaine intoxication? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Formication

 

Formication, characterized by the feeling of insects moving beneath the skin, is a notable occurrence in cases of cocaine abuse. This phenomenon is also commonly denoted as Magnan's syndrome or cocaine bugs.

 

COCAINE

 

  • Derived from the plant, Erythroxylum coca
  • Sigmund Freud studied its pharmacological effects and probably had an addiction to cocaine too.
  • Was initially used as a local anaesthetic (as it blocks fast sodium channels), especially for ENT surgeries.
  • Blocks dopamine and norepinephrine receptors (dopamine & NE reuptake is inhibited) resulting in-
    • Vasoconstriction: HTN, MI
    • Nasal septal perforation (nasal inhalation of cocaine results in nasal congestion and long-term use can cause nasal septal perforation)
    • Seizures
    • Jet black pigmentation of tongue
  • Routes of administration - Snorting (inhalation of finely powdered form into the nose), freebasing (smoking), I.V. and subcutaneous.

 

Intoxication

 

  • Euphoria
  • Sympathetic symptoms (tachycardia, palpitations, hypertension, sweating, mydriasis)
  • Paranoid ideations (persecutory ideations) + auditory hallucinations
  • Tactile hallucinations or cocaine bugs or magnan phenomenon or formication (sensation of insects crawling under the skin)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oneroid state is a dream-like fantastic delusional derangement of consciousness

 

Option C. Dipsomania is a historical term describing a medical condition involving an uncontrollable craving for alcohol or drugs.

 

Option D. Carphologia is a lint-picking behavior that is often a symptom of a delirious state.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Formication (the sensation of insects crawling under the skin) is a classic tactile hallucination associated with chronic cocaine intoxication, also known as Magnan’s phenomenon or “cocaine bugs.”

choices.text: Intra-abdominal infections

questions.text: Antimicrobial combinations are used in all except? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Gonorrhea

 

Drug of choice for treatment of gonorrhea is single dose ceftriaxone therapy. It does not require combination therapy.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. For Management of Tuberculosis, a combination of drugs consisting of Rifampicin, Isoniazid, Pyrazinamide and Ethambutol are used. In cases like MDR or XDR TB, other drugs like Bedaquiline, Levofloxacin, Ethionamide etc. are used in various combinations and in the form of different regimens.

 

Option C. Intraabdominal infections are generally polymicrobial in nature consisting of both aerobic and anaerobic microorganisms. Combination therapy with metronidazole and other agents like ciprofloxacin, cefepime, etc. are used as empirical agents to treat them.

 

Option D. Malaria: In case of Plasmodium vivax infection, Chloroquine is used for 3 days + Primaquine is added for 14 days. For P. Falciparum infection, combination therapy consisting of ACT-SP (Artesunate + Sulfadoxine + Pyrimethamine) are used along with a single dose of Primaquine on Day 2. For P. Falciparum infection in the north eastern states, ACT-AL (Artemether + Lumefantrine) is used.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antimicrobial combination therapy is not used for the treatment of gonorrhea, which is typically managed with single-dose ceftriaxone therapy. In contrast, tuberculosis, intra-abdominal infections, and malaria require combination therapy to effectively manage the infections and prevent resistance.

questions.text: Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) is used to relieve pain. What is the mechanism behind it? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gate control theory

 

Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) used for pain relief is based on the gate theory of pain.

 

According to gate control theory, the pain stimuli transmitted by afferent pain fibers are blocked by gate mechanism located at the posterior gray horn of spinal cord. If the gate is opened, pain is felt. If the gate is closed, pain is suppressed.

 

TENS activates a complex neuronal network using electrodes to result in a reduction in pain. At frequencies and intensities used clinically, TENS activates large diameter afferent fibers. This afferent input is sent to the central nervous system to activate descending inhibitory systems to reduce hyperalgesia. Specifically, blockade of neuronal activity in the periaqueductal gray (PAG), rostral ventromedial medulla (RVM) and spinal cord inhibit the analgesic effects of TENS showing that TENS analgesia is maintained through these pathways.

 

The given image depicts the gate control theory of pain:

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Conditioned pain modulation: This refers to the phenomenon where pain in one part of the body can reduce pain in another part, which is not directly related to the mechanism of TENS.

 

Option C. Descending inhibition: While TENS does activate descending inhibitory pathways, the primary mechanism described in the context of TENS for this question is the gate control theory.

 

Option D. Central inhibition: This refers to the inhibition of pain at the level of the central nervous system, which is a broader concept and not specific to the primary mechanism of TENS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) alleviates pain primarily through the gate control theory, which involves blocking pain signals at the spinal cord level by activating large-diameter afferent fibers.

questions.text:
The fibres of the internal oblique muscle and transversus abdominus muscle contribute to which boundaries of the inguinal canal walls? (INICET Nov 2023)

 

  1. Anterior wall
  2. Roof
  3. Floor
  4. Posterior wall
questions.solution:
Ans. A) ii and iv

 

 

 

The inguinal canal is an important structure in the anterior abdominal wall, with specific boundaries formed by different layers of muscles and fascia. The internal oblique is present in the lateral 1/3rd of anterior wall but transverse abdominis does not contribute to the anterior wall at all.

 

ii. Roof: The fibres of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles, along with their conjoint tendon, form the roof of the inguinal canal.

 

iv. Posterior wall: The conjoint tendon, formed by the joining of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles, also contributes to the posterior wall of the inguinal canal.

 

Other Options:

 

i. Anterior wall: The anterior wall of the inguinal canal is primarily formed by the external oblique aponeurosis, along with skin and superficial fascia. The internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles do not contribute to the anterior wall.

 

iii. Floor: The floor of the inguinal canal is formed by the inguinal ligament, not by the internal oblique or transversus abdominis muscles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles contribute to the roof and posterior wall of the inguinal canal through their conjoint tendon.

choices.text: Collect using your hand and discard in drain
Collect using paper/cardboard and put in water tube/bucket
Collect and throw outside in the environment
Broom it and discard in dustbin

questions.text: A medical student accidentally drops a sphygmomanometer, causing mercury spill on the floor. What is the most appropriate method to manage this spill? [INICET MAY 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Collect using paper/cardboard and put in water tube/bucket

 

  • Identify visible larger mercury beads and push together using Cardboards and collect using Syringe without needle.
  • Store collected mercury beads in an air tight plastic bag and label it properly. Put all the items that were used to pick up the mercury, including index cards or cardboard, eyedropper, contaminated tape, paper towels, and zipper-type bags into the trash bag. Carefully seal the trash bag that contains the mercury contaminated waste and dispose them properly.
  • Do not use a vacuum, broom or paint brush to clean up the spill. These methods can spread the mercury to other areas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most appropriate method to manage a mercury spill is to collect it using paper/cardboard and place it in a water tube or bucket, then ensure safe and proper disposal.
  • Avoid direct contact, vacuuming, or sweeping the mercury.

questions.text: A female presented with an ulcerated breast lump. Nipple retraction was seen, with some warmth and redness. On biopsy, it was diagnosed as invasive ductal carcinoma. According to AJCC 8th Ed., which of these correctly represents the stage? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) T4b

 

In the American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) 8th edition staging system, the classification of breast cancer stages is detailed based on tumor size, lymph node involvement, and the presence of metastasis.

 

The presentation of an ulcerated breast lump, nipple retraction, warmth, and redness suggests skin involvement, which is characteristic of a T4 classification. Specifically, the presence of ulceration and skin involvement corresponds to T4b. T4b is used when there is skin involvement in the form of ulceration, satellite skin nodules, or peau d’orange (skin changes resembling the texture of an orange).

 

While there is the possibility of inflammatory breast cancer due to the warmth and redness, the key feature here is ulceration, which is more indicative of T4b. Inflammatory breast cancer would correspond to a T4d classification, characterized by more extensive skin changes like diffuse erythema and edema (peau d'orange) involving more than one-third of the breast, often with underlying invasive ductal carcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stage IV with N1-N2 involvement: This is incorrect as there is no evidence of distant metastasis (M1), which is required for a Stage IV classification. The presence of regional lymph node involvement (N1-N2) alone does not justify a Stage IV classification.

 

Option C. Stage IIIB: This could be considered if the case were inflammatory breast cancer, but based on the ulceration and other features described, T4b is more appropriate unless additional evidence of inflammatory changes was present.

 

Option D. It cannot be M1: This statement is partially correct as the case does not mention any distant metastasis (M1), but it doesn’t address the primary tumor stage, which is the focus of the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ulceration of a breast lump with skin involvement typically corresponds to T4b in the AJCC 8th edition staging system for breast cancer. It is essential to differentiate between T4b and T4d (inflammatory breast cancer) based on the clinical presentation and pathological findings.

choices.text: 1, 3 and 4
1, 2 and 4
2, 3 and 4

questions.text:
Which of the following method of disinfection and sterilization can also kill spores? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Glutaraldehyde
  2. Ethylene oxide
  3. Pasteurization
  4. Ortho-phthalaldehyde
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2 and 4

 

Glutaraldehyde, Ethylene oxide, and Ortho-phthalaldehyde are effective methods of disinfection and sterilization that can kill spores.

 

1. Glutaraldehyde: This chemical is a broad-spectrum microbicidal and sporicidal agent. It is known for its compatibility with a variety of medical instruments. However, it requires activation and produces irritant fumes, which are notable disadvantages. Despite these drawbacks, glutaraldehyde is commonly recommended for the disinfection of fibroscopes and respiratory equipment due to its efficacy against spores and other microorganisms.

 

2. ETO (Ethylene oxide) inactivates all microorganisms although bacterial spores (especially B. atrophaeus) are more resistant than other microorganisms. For this reason B. atrophaeus is the recommended biological indicator. ETO is used in healthcare facilities to sterilize critical items (and sometimes semicritical items) that are moisture or heat sensitive and cannot be sterilized by steam sterilization like syringes, needles, catheters, and gloves. Bacillus atrophaeus and Bacillus subtilis are used as sterilization control.

 

4. Ortho-phthalaldehyde: Similar to glutaraldehyde, ortho-phthalaldehyde is a broad-spectrum microbicidal and sporicidal agent. It does not require activation and does not produce irritating fumes, which are significant advantages. However, it is costly and can stain medical equipment. It is often used as an alternative to glutaraldehyde for disinfecting scopes.

 

Other Options

 

3. Pasteurization or pasteurization is a process of food preservation in which packaged and non-packaged foods (such as milk and fruit juices) are treated with mild heat, usually to less than 100 °C (212 °F), to eliminate pathogens and extend shelf life. It has no sporicidal activity and kills non-spore-forming bacteria like Mycobacteria, Brucella, and Salmonella. There are two methods-

 

  1. Holder method -  milk is heated at either 63°C for 30 minutes. Coxiella burnetii is relatively heat resistant and may survive the holder method.
  2. Flash method - milk is heated at 72°C for 15-20 seconds followed by cooling quickly to 13°C or lower.

 

Educational Objective

choices.text: A, B and C
B and C only
B and D

questions.text:
Which of the following drugs are used for absence seizures? (INICET Nov 2020)

 

A. Carbamazepine

B. Valproate

C. Ethosuximide

D. Gabapentin
questions.solution:
Ans. B. B and C only

 

The first line drugs for treatment of absence seizures are valproate and ethosuximide. Carbamazepine and phenytoin are contra-indicated in absence seizures.

 

Drugs Used in Absence Seizures

 

  • Ethosuximide: This drug is specific for absence seizures. It works by blocking T-type calcium channels in the thalamus, which are believed to play a role in the generation of absence seizures.
  • Valproic Acid (Valproate): Valproate is effective in treating a wide range of seizure types, including absence seizures. It works by increasing GABA levels and blocking sodium and calcium channels. Valproate is also used for bipolar disorder and migraine prophylaxis.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Carbamazepine: Carbamazepine is not used for absence seizures. In fact, it can exacerbate absence seizures. It is typically used for partial seizures and generalized tonic-clonic seizures.

 

Options D. Gabapentin: Gabapentin is not effective for absence seizures. It is mainly used for neuropathic pain and as an adjunctive treatment for partial seizures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DRUGS USED IN ABSENCE SEIZURES

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of HIV is started on combined active antiretroviral therapy (cART). After few months of treatment, he develops palmo-plantar hyperpigmentation. What is the most likely drug implicated in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Emtricitabine


Emtricitabine is an NRTI (Nucleoside Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitor) which can lead to hyperpigmentation of the palms and soles.

 

Other options:


Option A. Nelfinavir is a protease inhibitor. It can cause diarrhea or loose stools, dyslipidemia, lipodystrophy and hyperlipidemia.


Option C. Abacavir is an NRTI that can lead to Steven Johnson Syndrome.


Option D. Zidovudine is an NRTI that can cause nail hyperpigmentation, bone marrow suppression, myopathy, hepatotoxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Emtricitabine, an NRTI used in the treatment of HIV, is known to cause palmo-plantar hyperpigmentation as a side effect. This differentiates it from other antiretroviral medications such as nelfinavir, abacavir, and zidovudine, which have different side effect profiles.

questions.text: The SRY gene is located in which of the following chromosomal regions? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Short arm of Y chromosome

 

Explanation

 

  • The SRY gene is located on the short arm (p-arm) of the Y chromosome (Yp11). This gene is often referred to as the "master switch" for male development. It codes for a transcription factor that triggers the development of testes in an embryo, which, in turn, leads to the development of male reproductive structures.

 

  • It is an intron less sex-determining gene on the Y chromosome.

 

 

 

Y- chromosome 

 

The SRY (Sex-determining Region Y) gene is a critical genetic region responsible for initiating male sex determination and the development of male reproductive organs in mammals, including humans. Let's discuss the location of the SRY region in detail for each option:

 

Other Options:

 

Option B) Short arm of X chromosome: Incorrect. The SRY gene is not located on the X chromosome. It is specific to the Y chromosome and plays a pivotal role in male sex determination.

 

Option C) Long arm of Y chromosome: Incorrect. The SRY gene is not on the long arm (q-arm) of the Y chromosome. It is situated on the short arm, as mentioned earlier.

 

Option D) Long arm of X chromosome: Incorrect. The SRY gene is not present on the X chromosome. It is unique to the Y chromosome and is responsible for the differentiation of the bipotential gonad into the testis during early embryonic development.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sex- determining region Y protein (SRY) gene or TDF ( Testis-determining factor ) is a DNA binding protein encoded by the SRY gene that is responsible for the initiation of male sex determination in mammals. Its expression causes the development of primary sex cords, which later develop into seminiferous tubules.

questions.text: Identify the pathognomonic structure in the slide given below? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sclerotic body

 

The histopathological picture shows brown coloured thick walled round cells that have transverse septations within them. These are called as Sclerotic bodies, also known as muriform cells or Medlar bodies, or copper penny appearance a found in tissue biopsies of patients with chromoblastomycosis. These bodies are a key diagnostic feature of this fungal infection.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Budding yeast: This is a general term for yeast cells reproducing through budding. It is not pathognomonic for a specific disease without further context.

 

Option C. Negri body are intracytoplasmic, round purplish structures with basophilic inner granules. They are pathognomic of rabies.

 

 

Option D. Asteroid body are oval, basophilic structure with eosinophilic radiation. They are antigen-antibody complexes deposits. Seen in sporotricosis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Few Important Pathognomonic structures associated with disease:

choices.text: Cyst is opened and drainage done

questions.text: Incorrect statement about choledocal cyst is: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cyst is opened and drainage done 

 

The preferred treatment for choledochal cysts is not merely opening and draining them, but rather complete surgical removal of the cyst (cyst excision) and reconstruction of the biliary drainage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased risk of cholangiocarcinoma: The risk of cholangiocarcinoma in patients with choledochal cysts can be significantly higher than in the general population. Regular monitoring and prophylactic surgical intervention are often recommended to manage this risk.

 

Option C. Todani classification used for grading: The Todani classification is indeed used to categorize choledochal cysts based on their anatomical location and type. This classification helps guide the treatment approach and prognostic assessment, making it fundamental in the management of choledochal cysts.

 

Option D. Associated with abnormal biliopancreatic junction: Choledochal cysts are often associated with an abnormal junction of the pancreatic and biliary ducts. This anomaly can lead to pancreatic juices refluxing into the bile duct, increasing the risk of inflammation and subsequent complications like cyst formation and malignancy.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While the management of choledochal cysts involves a comprehensive approach considering the risk of malignancy, the appropriate surgical intervention usually entails the complete removal of the cyst and careful reconstruction of the biliary system, not just simple drainage.

questions.text: A young girl presented with a history of multiple episodes of loss of consciousness that lasted for 5-10 minutes. These episodes occur only in front of family members and only in the daytime. The patient can recall the conversation that happened around her during these episodes; there is no history of tongue bite and no incontinence. What is the preferred treatment? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Treat with behavioral therapy

  

The patient's symptoms—episodes of apparent loss of consciousness only occurring in front of family members, during the day, with the ability to recall surrounding conversations—suggest that these are not true seizures but pseudoseizures, which are commonly associated with conversion disorder.

 

Conversion disorder is characterized by neurological symptoms without a medical or neurological cause, often triggered by psychological factors.

 

Behavioral therapy is the preferred treatment for conversion disorder. This approach helps the patient address and modify the underlying psychological factors contributing to their symptoms through techniques such as cognitive restructuring, relaxation techniques, and coping strategies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Treat with aversive therapy: Aversive therapy involves applying unpleasant stimuli to reduce the occurrence of undesirable behaviors. It is considered unethical, especially in treating psychological disorders like conversion disorder, because it can cause harm and does not address the underlying psychological issues.

 

Option C. Valproate: Valproate is an antiepileptic medication used to treat true seizures, but it is not appropriate for conversion disorder or pseudoseizures since the condition is psychological rather than neurological.

 

Option D.  Ketogenic diet: The ketogenic diet is sometimes used to manage epilepsy but is not suitable for conversion disorder. The diet has no role in addressing psychological origins of symptoms like pseudoseizures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The preferred treatment for conversion disorder, which manifests with pseudoseizures, is behavioral therapy, not antiepileptic drugs or other seizure management strategies.

choices.text: The assertion is independently a true statement, but the reasons is independently a false statement.
The assertion is independently a false statement, but the reasons is independently a true statement.
Both assertion and reason are true statements
Both assertion and reason are false statements

questions.text:
Assertion: Resting membrane potential is dependent on proteins and phosphate ions.

 

Reason: Diffusion potential can be calculated using Nernst Equation. (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both assertion and reason are true statements

 

Resting membrane potential refers to the electrical charge difference across the cell membrane of a neuron or other excitable cells when the cell is at rest, meaning it is not actively transmitting signals. This potential is maintained by the uneven distribution of ions, primarily sodium (Na+), potassium (K+), chloride (Cl-), and other negative ions, across the cell membrane.

 

Nernst equation is used to calculate the diffusion potential (also known as the equilibrium potential) for a specific ion across a semi-permeable membrane.

 

 

Where:

 

  • E is the equilibrium potential for the ion.
  • R is the ideal gas constant.
  • T is the absolute temperature (in Kelvin).
  • z is the valence (charge) of the ion.
  • F is Faraday's constant.
  • [Cout]​ and [Cin]​ are the concentrations of the ion outside and inside the membrane, respectively.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Resting membrane potential is maintained by the uneven distribution of ions, primarily sodium (Na+), potassium (K+), chloride (Cl-), and other negative ions (including proteins and phosphate ions), across the cell membrane.
  • The Nernst equation is used to calculate the diffusion potential (also known as the equilibrium potential) for a specific ion across a semi-permeable membrane.

questions.text: An experiment is being conducted on a dog blood pressure to study the effect of acetylcholine. The blood pressure is recorded at each intervention and is shown below. What does phase 4 in the graph indicate? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Nicotinic action of acetylcholine

 

For demonstrating nicotinic actions (on ganglia) of acetylcholine, two criteria are required:

 

  • High dose of acetylcholine (around 5 mg).
  • Muscarinic receptors must be blocked by giving atropine (to avoid death of the animal due to overactivity of muscarinic receptors)

 

About the given graph:

 

 

  • In phases 1 and 2, Acetylcholine is given at doses of 2 mcg and 50 mcg. This leads to a drop in the BP due to its action in the muscarinic receptors.
  • In phase 3 when its muscarinic action is blocked by atropine, administration of 50 mcg of Acetylcholine does not cause a fall in BP.
  • But in phase 4, when Ach is administered at higher dose of 5 mg, it acts on the Neuronal Nicotinic receptors located in CNS, ganglia and adrenals, leading to their stimulation and release of norepinephrine, which causes the BP to shoot up. Thus, Phase 4 in the graph indicates the nicotinic action of acetylcholine at higher doses.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Muscarinic action of acetylcholine: Muscarinic actions are demonstrated in Phases 1 and 2, where acetylcholine causes a drop in blood pressure. This option is incorrect for Phase 4.

 

Option B. Potentiation of acetylcholine: Potentiation would suggest an increased effect due to repeated or combined actions, which is not the primary mechanism demonstrated in Phase 4.

 

Option C. Antagonism of acetylcholine: Antagonism would imply inhibition of acetylcholine’s effects. Phase 3 demonstrates antagonism (by atropine) but not Phase 4.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phase 4 in the graph indicates the nicotinic action of acetylcholine, characterized by a rise in blood pressure due to the stimulation of neuronal nicotinic receptors after administering a high dose of acetylcholine (5 mg) following the blockade of muscarinic receptors with atropine.

choices.text: If the hands are visibly soiled
While moving from a contaminated site to a clean site during patient care

questions.text: A healthcare worker is performing patient care in a hospital setting. Which of the following is not a correct situation for using hand rub according to standard hand hygiene protocol? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) If the hands are visibly soiled

 

Hand rub, typically alcohol-based hand sanitizer, is not effective when hands are visibly soiled or contaminated with dirt, blood, or other body fluids. In such cases, healthcare workers should wash their hands with soap and water to physically remove the visible contaminants before using hand rub. This is a crucial step to ensure proper hand hygiene.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. While moving from a contaminated site to a clean site during patient care: Correct. Healthcare workers should use hand rub when transitioning from a contaminated site to a clean site during patient care. This helps prevent the spread of pathogens and maintain aseptic conditions. It's an essential practice in infection control

 

Option C. Before donning on gloves: Correct. Hand hygiene, including the use of hand rub, is recommended before putting on gloves. This step ensures that any potential contaminants on the hands are removed before glove use, reducing the risk of contamination during procedures .

 

Option D. During direct patient contact: Correct. Healthcare workers should use hand rub before and after direct patient contact to reduce the risk of transmitting pathogens to or from the patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hand hygiene is essential for infection prevention in healthcare settings. Alcohol-based hand rubs are preferred in most cases, but soap and water should be used for visibly soiled hands and in cases of outbreaks of certain pathogens like Clostridium difficile. Hand hygiene should be performed before and after every direct patient contact, before donning gloves, and after removing gloves. Additionally, hand hygiene should be performed while moving from a contaminated site to a clean site during patient care. It is important to note that using hand rub is not appropriate if the hands are visibly soiled, as the rub cannot effectively remove dirt and debris from the hands. In such cases, soap and water handwashing is recommended.

choices.text: Presence of benzalkonium bromide in the preparation
Associated use of hypertonic saline in nebulizer

questions.text: All of the following can be the mechanism for paradoxical bronchoconstriction seen with the use of ipratropium bromide Except? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Prejunctional M2 receptor stimulation

 

Pre-synaptic muscarinic M2 receptors inhibit the release of acetylcholine which is a potent bronchoconstrictor. Therefore, presynaptic stimulation of these receptors will result in bronchodilation, not constriction. On the other hand, ipratropium can cause transient bronchoconstriction initially, one the reason is blockade (not stimulation) of the pre-synaptic receptors resulting in more release of acetylcholine.

 

  • Paradoxical bronchoconstriction with ipratropium bromide, particularly when given by nebulizer, were largely explained as:

    • Effects of the hypertonic nebulizer solution

    • Antibacterial additives, such as benzalkonium chloride and EDTA.

    • Presynaptic blockade (not stimulation) of muscarinic (M2) receptors

  • This problem has not been described with tiotropium bromide or other LAMAs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Presence of benzalkonium bromide in the preparation: Benzalkonium bromide is a preservative that can cause bronchoconstriction in susceptible individuals when used in nebulized medications.

 

Option C. Associated use of hypertonic saline in nebuliser: Hypertonic saline can irritate the airways and lead to bronchoconstriction, which can explain paradoxical reactions during nebulization.

 

Option D. Presence of EDTA as impurity: EDTA, used as a stabilizing agent in some formulations, can also cause bronchoconstriction by irritating the airways

 

Educational Objective:

 

Paradoxical bronchoconstriction associated with ipratropium bromide is not caused by prejunctional M2 receptor stimulation. Instead, it can be caused by the presence of benzalkonium bromide, use of hypertonic saline, and presence of EDTA as impurities, which can all irritate the airways and lead to bronchoconstriction.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient with a history of prior neck radiation for lymphoma is diagnosed with 2 x 3 cm papillary thyroid cancer. No lymph node enlargement is present. What is the treatment? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Total thyroidectomy

 

Explanation: 

 

Total thyroidectomy is now the preferred approach only for those differentiated thyroid cancers (DTCs) at higher risk for recurrence:

  • Tumor at least  4 cm 
  • Gross extrathyroidal extension 
  • Evidence of metastatic disease 
  • Radiation-induced DTC (mentioned in the history) 
  • Familial non-medullary thyroid cancer 
  • Multifocal bilateral DTC.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemithyroidectomy:

 

  • History of radiation is a high-risk feature requiring total thyroidectomy
  • Hemithyroidectomy is reserved for low-risk, small unifocal tumors without risk factors

 

Option C. Hemithyroidectomy + MRND:

 

  • MRND is not indicated without clinical lymphadenopathy
  • MRND is mainly done for medullary thyroid cancer
  • Hemithyroidectomy is inadequate given the radiation history

 

Option D. Total Thyroidectomy + MRND:

 

  • No lymph node involvement noted
  • For papillary thyroid cancer without lymphadenopathy, central compartment (level VI) clearance may be done, but not MRND

 

Educational Objective: 

 

History of radiation exposure is an absolute indication for total thyroidectomy in differentiated thyroid cancer, regardless of tumor size.

choices.text: Forced expiration against a closed glottis
Forced expiration against an open glottis
Forced inspiration against a closed glottis

questions.text: Which of the following occur during the beginning cough reflex? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Forced expiration against a closed glottis

 

The cough reflex begins with a forced expiration against a closed glottis. The pressure builds up in the lungs and, when the glottis opens, it allows for a rapid expulsion of air to clear the airways.
