Other Options:

 

Option B. Forced expiration against an open glottis: This does not occur during a cough reflex. While the glottis does eventually open to allow air to be expelled, the characteristic high-pressure expulsion of air is the result of the closed glottis after which it opens.

 

Option C. Forced inspiration against a closed glottis: Inspiration occurs with an open glottis. A closed glottis would prevent air from entering the lungs, so this does not occur during the cough reflex.

 

Option D. None of the above: This option is incorrect because option (a) accurately describes an event that occurs during the cough reflex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The beginning of the cough reflex involves a forced expiration against a closed glottis, building up pressure in the lungs which is then rapidly released when the glottis opens.Top of Form

questions.text: Phospholipase C acts via which of the following G protein-coupled receptors?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Gq 

 

Phospholipase C acts via the Gq type of G protein-coupled receptors. It leads to the activation of the IP3-DAG pathway. The receptors that act via this pathway include the receptors of H1, α1, M1, V1, M3, Angiotensin II, Gastrin, GnRH, Oxytocin and TRH.


Important points about GPCR:

 

G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) are cell membrane receptors that span across the membrane 7 times (heptahelical). Subtypes of GPCRs are distinguished by their alpha subunits. The important subtypes of GPCRs are Gs, Gp, Gq, and Go. GPCRs act via various second messengers. The important ones with their action on the effector are:

 

  • Gs causes activation of adenylyl cyclase and thus increase in cAMP.
  • Gi causes inhibition of adenylyl cyclase and thus decrease in cAMP.
  • Go causes Ca2+ channel inhibition.
  • Gq causes activation of phospholipase C which generates the second messengers inositol trisphosphate (IP3) and diacylglycerol (DAG). It helps in mobilizing Ca2+ form the endoplasmic reticulum stores.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phospholipase C (PLC) is activated by Gq-coupled receptors, which in turn generate the second messengers IP3 and DAG, leading to various downstream effects, including the mobilization of calcium ions from intracellular stores.

choices.text: Screening tests define risk of passing genetic disorder
Screening tests are more accurate than diagnostic tests

questions.text: A genetic counsellor is discussing various types of genetic tests with a couple planning for a child. Which of the following statements accurately describes genetic screening? [INICET MAY 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Screening tests define risk of passing genetic disorder

 

Genetic screening/testing

 

  • Genetic testing is a type of medical test that identifies changes in genes, chromosomes, or proteins. 
  • It is a process to analyse blood or skin for the systematic search for persons with a particular genotype in a defined population (usually invasive procedures)
  • In order to locate this faulty gene, scientists search for variations in larger pieces of DNA called "markers", latter are found nearby the DNA and become the basis of genetic screening
  • The results of a genetic test can confirm or rule out a suspected genetic condition or help determine a person's chance of developing or passing on a genetic. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Screening tests are more accurate than diagnostic tests: Incorrect. Screening tests assess risk and are not as definitive as diagnostic tests, which provide a precise diagnosis.

 

Option C. Screening requires genetic mapping: Incorrect. Genetic screening does not necessarily involve genetic mapping, which is a detailed analysis of the entire genome.

 

Option D. Involve invasive procedures: Incorrect. Screening tests can often be performed using non-invasive methods such as blood or saliva samples, although some genetic tests may require invasive procedures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Genetic screening tests are used to define the risk of passing on a genetic disorder and can help determine the likelihood of developing a genetic condition.
  • They are not as definitive as diagnostic tests and do not necessarily involve invasive procedures or genetic mapping.

choices.text: Need for drug monitoring
ECG monitoring for arrhythmias
Sedation being the side effect

questions.text: A patient was treated with imipramine for a major depressive episode in the hospital for 4 weeks. What is the main concern while considering his discharge from the hospital?(INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C.  Suicidal risk

 

The main concern while considering the discharge of a patient who has been treated with imipramine for a major depressive episode is Suicidal Risk.

 

Suicidal risk is a critical concern when discharging patients who have been treated for major depression. The risk of suicide can actually increase as the patient begins to recover, partly because they may gain more energy and motivation before their mood improves significantly. Further TCA are lethal in overdose. Therefore, ensuring that the patient has a safe environment, a follow-up plan, and appropriate support upon discharge is crucial.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Need for Drug Monitoring: While some level of monitoring is advisable when a patient is on imipramine, especially for tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) blood levels in certain cases, it is not typically the primary concern at discharge for depression treatment.

 

Options B. ECG Monitoring for Arrhythmias: Although TCAs like imipramine can have cardiac side effects, including arrhythmias, and may warrant ECG monitoring, particularly in older adults or those with pre-existing heart conditions, it's not usually the primary concern at the point of discharge unless the patient has a known cardiac issue.

 

Options D. Sedation Being the Side Effect: While sedation can be a side effect of imipramine, it is generally not the main concern at discharge. The more pressing issue is the patient's mental health stability and safety.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The main concern when discharging a patient treated with imipramine for a major depressive episode is the risk of suicide. This requires ensuring that the patient has a safe environment, a follow-up plan, and appropriate support to manage their mental health effectively after discharge.

questions.text: An HIV patient presents with seizures and neck rigidity. The CSF examination shows the presence of organisms on India ink and a diagnosis of cryptococcal meningitis is made. Which of the following anti-fungal drug is used for initial treatment of this meningitis? (Fmge Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Liposomal amphotericin

 

Cryptococcal meningitis is a serious fungal infection commonly seen in immunocompromised patients, such as those with HIV/AIDS. The initial treatment aims to rapidly reduce the fungal burden in the central nervous system (CNS).

 

  • Liposomal Amphotericin B: This is the drug of choice for the initial treatment of cryptococcal meningitis. Liposomal formulations of amphotericin B are preferred because they are less nephrotoxic and have a better safety profile compared to conventional amphotericin B. Amphotericin B works by binding to ergosterol in the fungal cell membrane, creating pores that lead to cell death.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. High dose fluconazole: While fluconazole is used in the treatment of cryptococcal meningitis, it is typically used for maintenance therapy after the initial reduction of fungal burden by amphotericin B and flucytosine. High-dose fluconazole is not as effective as liposomal amphotericin B for initial treatment.

 

Option C. Fluconazole + 5 Flucytosine: This combination can be used, but the standard initial treatment for cryptococcal meningitis is liposomal amphotericin B with flucytosine. Fluconazole is more commonly used for maintenance therapy after the initial phase.

 

Option D. Voriconazole: Voriconazole is used primarily for aspergillosis and some other fungal infections but is not the first-line treatment for cryptococcal meningitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For the initial treatment of cryptococcal meningitis, especially in immunocompromised patients such as those with HIV/AIDS, liposomal amphotericin B is the preferred drug due to its efficacy in rapidly reducing the fungal burden in the CNS and its better safety profile compared to conventional amphotericin B. Fluconazole is used for maintenance therapy following the initial treatment phase.
